stories.text:
We are currently looking for some Beta testers (preferably with Amazon selling experience) to give us some additional feedback on our product research tool.

Esparkify offers a suite of Amazon tools that help sellers discover winning product ideas, estimate sales, keyword optimization for listings, and spy on competitors all from a single dashboard. Our tools simplify the product research process and enable sellers of every caliber to stay competitive, save time, decrease risks, and make more informed decisions that are backed by real data extracted directly from Amazon.

Currently includes our flagship product research tool, with Amazon chrome extension and keyword research tool currently in development.

Sign up on https://esparkify.com/ to become a beta tester today, and get exclusive offers like free 3-month access and discount codes when we launch.
stories.title: Esparkify: Amazon Seller Tool looking for Beta Testers

stories.text:
Besides the annoyance from all the recruiter spam, I'm also "worried" about the abysmal productivity of the average recruiter.

When I get contacted by headhunters I can't count the number of times where I had to exchange 5, 6, 7 messages... to get maybe 20% of what's on the real public job posting on the company's website(and on top of that sometimes they give me incorrect information!), just to end up telling them that I'm not interested. Surely they can do better than that?

I can't count how many times I got contacted for on-sites jobs when I only do full remote, for expert java jobs when I do JS, for senior roles when I'm a junior.(and some of those people were unicorns internal recruiters!!!)

How do these people stay in business?

How would put them out of business?(or help them act less stupid, but I doubt that's possible)
stories.title: Ask HN: How would you fix tech recruiting?
Intel Goes Full XPU: Falcon Shores to Combine x86 and Xe for Supercomputers
New Atomic Clocks Measure Time Dilation at Millimeter Scale

stories.text:
https://stripe.com/treasury

I was very excited about it, but turns out you can't use it for one of the most interesting use cases imo, personal banking.

Are there other platforms that would allow me to form a "virtual banking provider"?

- Being able to issue people cards for personal use - Assign those cards to individual ACH-enabled accounts

I'd especially love a platform that doesn't require sales calls to get started since it seems like they tend to be tuned for established players.
stories.title: Stripe Treasury/Issuance Alternatives?
Nhtsa Begins Preliminary Investigation into Tesla “Phantom Breaking” [pdf]
Russian hackers obtained defense information technology targeting US contractors

stories.text: 'What makes something a community?' is a question I ask myself frequently. I think HN tends to like to get meta about HN - but it leads me to wonder what people mean when they mention "the community." Do you consider yourself part of the "HN Community?" Why or why not?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is Hacker News a “Community?”
